docs.lead_paragraph: Cognitive therapy was developed 40 years ago to treat people suffering from depression. But in the age of Prozac and other newer antidepressants, said Dr. Judith Beck, director of the Beck Institute for Cognitive Therapy and Research, ''we don't see them in our offices anymore.'' The patients who do seek cognitive therapy these days tend to have more longstanding, and more complicated, problems. And in response, the therapy is being modified and adapted to meet their needs.

headline.main: A Therapy Modified For Patient And Times

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Aaron T Beck, founder of cognitive therapy, and his daughter, Dr Judith Beck; they describe treating patients with depression, and borderline personality disorder (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hannah, 15 months old, has been plagued by recurring ear and sinus infections -- eight infections in eight months. Four different antibiotics have failed to control the problem, which stems in part from the colds her 5-year-old sister brings home from kindergarten. An ear, nose and throat specialist recommended surgery to place tubes in her ears and to remove her adenoids to relieve the congestion that fosters the infections. Her reluctant parents sought a second opinion from another specialist, who questioned the need for an adenoidectomy and said it would be perfectly safe to wait before considering ear tube surgery.

headline.main: For Baby's Ear Infection, Check Options

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on ear infections in children; drawing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pushed by rising costs for prescription drugs and insurance premiums, growth in the nation's health care bill accelerated in 1998. Private health care spending increased by 6.9 percent, as against a 4.8 percent rise in 1997. Growth in government spending, on programs like Medicare, for the elderly and disabled, slowed to 4.1 percent, according to an annual report by the Health Care Financing Administration.

headline.main: U.S. Health Care Costs Rose Faster in 1998

docs.abstract: Growth in nation's health-care bill accelerates in 1998, pushed by rising costs for prescription drugs and insurance premiums; private health care spending increases by 6.9 percent, compared with 4.8 percent rise in 1997; growth in government spending, on programs like Medicare, for elderly and disabled, slows to 4.1 percent; overall, health care spending rises to $4,094 per person in 1998, or total of $1.1 trillion, from $3,912 per person in 1997 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I have eaten nearly 400 eggs since July. Scrambled, mostly. A few over medium. At home, I fry them in a pool of butter or, better yet, bacon grease. I add some cream while scrambling, a little cheese while cooking. At a hotel or restaurant, I'll go with an omelette, thick with sausage or cheddar (or both).

headline.main: Low-Carb Diet: Lose the Bun, Not the Burger (and Heavy on the Mayo)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the weeks before Jan. 1, the number of calls to hot lines, and their sense of foreboding, increased enough that some crisis centers around the country increased their staffs and braced for the possibility of a millennial surge in attempted suicides. The historic significance of this year's calendar change, for some sufferers of depression, represented ''a definite line of demarcation'' that seemed impossible to get past, according to Reese Butler, director of the National Hope Line Network, a nonprofit network of 19 crisis centers that is based in Vallejo, Calif.

headline.main: Double Watch, for the Millennium and Suicide

docs.abstract: Crisis centers around country, concerned about potential millenial surge in suicides, increased their staffs and braced for an increase, but report there was no rash of suicides (M)
